fields.description:
Our Stash instance is accessible via multiple URLs (legacy DNS). We're seeing problems with pull request attachments, where the URL of the attachment is based on the URL that the user accessed the application with.

E.g.

https://mystash:443
http://mystash:7990
https://mystash.alt-dns:443

This results in some confusion - sometimes I can't see an attachment (because I'm not logged in on the URL it's being served from). Sometimes, due to DNS issues, I can't even see the attachment at all (e.g. if the primary DNS is down).

My expectation is that the attachment URL would be based on my current URL, not the uploader's URL at the time.
fields.summary: Inconsistent pull request attachment URLs

fields.description: As is now, Stash only allows comments within 10 lines of a change ("Comments can only be added within 10 lines of a change"). This is extremely frustrating. There are times during a code review that I need to comment that something needs to change, but hasn't changed in the file (example, an unchanged method should change). Since it hasn't changed in the file, I can't add a comment that it should change.
fields.summary: Ability to comment anywhere in the code

fields.description:
If I disable all branch prefixes, but have two different branches in "Development" and "Production", I can't save with setting "Enable automatic merging".
Ic can click it, but after saving, the checkbox is no longer checked.

I think, by using two different branches, merging to "Production" should also merge to "Development".
fields.summary: Support automatic merge between production and development branch

fields.description:
The markup for h3-h6 have font-weight set to bold and not h1-h2. This is difficult to tell which has the greater emphasis between h2 and h3.

Request the increase font weight for h1 and h2 or remove the font weight for h3-h6.

Screenshot like the following:
"Project" (h2) and "AzureHost..." (h3)
http://puu.sh/ePld9/c1476b381e.png

Both in h2
http://puu.sh/ePlsV/fdbb6dea52.png
Both in h3
http://puu.sh/ePlp7/55db5683ac.png
fields.summary: Markdown Formatting Inconsistency

fields.description:
as it is stated in this discussion: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/11967228/stash-backup-client-why-do-we-have-a-timeout-waiting-for-scm-drain

there is a setting in the stash-config.properties file to define the timeout for database drain: backup.drain.database.timeout

But currently I have pretty bigs git projects that take more than 1 minute to be cloned, and as I have constant cloning due to Continuus Integration system, this breack my backup with a timeout due to scm activities that are not ended in time.

Could we have a setting like backup.drain.scm.timeout or any other solution that allow to drain scm activities even if they take more than 1 minute? In it current state, backup is broken for big projects in very active environments.
fields.summary: As a Stash administrator, I want to set the drain scm timeout to more than 1 minute, so that I can face to scm activities that take longer time before starting my backup process

fields.description: It lacks the ability to compare commits. Only able to compare HEAD of branches.
fields.summary: Ability to compare commits

fields.description: When viewing a commit, it's trivial to be able to browse the code at that time. It's lacking a "Browse Code" link that goes to ?at=COMMIT_HASH
fields.summary: Browse code (file tree) at some time

fields.description:
If branch name is long it will be ellipticized and then there is no way to copy branch name from pr.

p.s. works fine on github
fields.summary: While in PR there is no way to copy branch name if it is long

fields.description:
I would like to view my (or another user's) public SSH key.

Unfortunately, currently I can only see a prefix of the key.

I should be able to click, and see the full key.

*For those interested in checking the keys, there are still two ways of doing this*:
# Hover the key with the mouse pointer, so the full key will be shown.
# Use REST API functions to retrieve the keys for projects and repositories:
#* For project: GET method of the function [/rest/keys/1.0/projects/\{projectKey\}/ssh|https://developer.atlassian.com/static/rest/bitbucket-server/4.5.2/bitbucket-ssh-rest.html#idp308112]
#* For repository: GET method of the function [/rest/keys/1.0/projects/\{projectKey\}/repos/\{repositorySlug\}/ssh|https://developer.atlassian.com/static/rest/bitbucket-server/4.5.2/bitbucket-ssh-rest.html#idp330368]
fields.summary: View full public SSH key/fingerprint for users and access keys

fields.description:
In Confluence, we have a few noteworthy branches:

 * {{master}} - current bleeding edge (5.8)
 * {{release/5.7}} - mainline for the 5.7 release series
 * {{release/5.6}} - mainline for the 5.6 release series
 * {{releease/etc}} - you get the point.

A common scenario is for someone to open a PR against {{release/5.7}}, merge it to that branch, then manually merge it across to master. In this case, the blame hook still sends a notification.

Ideally, it would notice that the commits being merged to master were in a PR against a different target branch, and be okay with them being manually merged to master without a corresponding PR.
fields.summary: HipChat Master Push Blame Hook doesn't handle more advanced workflows

fields.description:
It would be nice to have at least basic filter/sorting/search in pull requests.
Or maybe I missed something and it is all already there?
fields.summary: Basic search/filter/sorting in pull request

fields.description:
If you go repository settings and try to select repository url, so you can use it somewhere else, you will have no luck.

Selection is reset all the time you try to select it.
fields.summary: Selection of repository url doesn't work

fields.description: This would be really nice feature so we can see all changes on one page like in Github
fields.summary: One page diff like in Github

fields.description: This would be really nice to have custom icon for each repository.
fields.summary: Icon customization per repository

fields.description:
This would really nice to be able to clear "recently viewed".

Since right now if you accidentally open any repository, it will be added to your list. Also items in this list is sorted by name, which result in repositories that is used often be somewhere in the middle of the list. Which one is harder to find.
fields.summary: Add a way to clear recently viewed

fields.description: When you double click on branch name in pull request it will select whole line, this makes it really hard to copy branch name.
fields.summary: In PR double click on branch name selects whole line

fields.description:
Earlier this week, we split out a couple dozen repos into a new project.  With a API, this would have taken a minute at most; but with the GUI it took about 45.  As this won't be the last time we have to move repos, I request a new REST endpoint for this.

As a general point, I argue that *anything* and *everything* that can be done with the GUI should be available via the API.
fields.summary: Document REST API for moving repo

fields.description:
We are updating our stash instances and used the backup-client to save all our data before proceeding. The backup failed at the database backup step and just stopped running. Our stash instance is now locked. We tried the following:

1. Unlocking it via the Web interface, but, as described in STASH-5182, this does not work. 
2. Use the REST maintenance API to manually unlock the instance, but we got a 404 status code while specifying the given token. 

How can we unlock the stash instance? We are neither able to connect to its Web interface, nor to start another backup (the "lock" request seems to be running forever).
fields.summary: Can't unlock stash neither cancel backup

fields.description: Branches should display the JIRA's Issue key as a column as well.
fields.summary: Display Issue key column on the Branch

fields.description:
Today while working on a PR, stash.a.c showed up a yellow banner:

{quote}Stash is queueing requests. Pushes, pulls, pull request merges and clones may take longer than expected. stash.web.scm.queueing.busy.help.html[http://docs.atlassian.com/stash/docs-036/Scaling+Stash, Scaling Stash]{quote}

This banner contained an unresolved template macro. I've raised the severity to major due to the bug being very visually present.

(Atlassian Stash v3.6.0-rc6)
fields.summary: Stash warning about queueing requests contains unresolved template macro

fields.description:
Bonjour,
Aujourd’hui, je suis bloqué sur l’ajout de nouveaux users Stash (Git). 
Voir l’erreur rencontrée ci-dessous.
Ensuite, lorsque je vérifie la licence, je constate qu’il reste encore 11 users « ajoutables ». Ce chiffre est exact, j’ai recompté tous les users qui sont déjà ajoutés et qui sont au nombre de 39/50. 

Merci de nous aider à débloquer la situation.
Si vous avez besoin de plus d’information Mr Philippe HENG reste disponible au 01 71 09 60 38.
Ainsi que l’exploitation au 01 71 11 04 04.
fields.summary: Stash : licence bloquée

fields.description:
On diff page, both left panel and right panel have too short scroll bar that I cannot see full content of a pull request. It occurs in Firefox and Chrome (only those two were tested)
It looks like it's OS depend as it works flawlessly on window 7 in both Firefox and Chrome.
fields.summary: Vertical scrolling is too short on diff page when license banner present

fields.description:
When I open a pull request I see a view with three tabs; Overview, Diff and Commits. This is great. 
When I enter one of the commits to view its content there is no way for me to get back to the particular pull request. We prefer to go through the individual commits during our reviews and we have to click on the pull request menu button on the navigation bar and find our review every time we want to get back.

Could you have a back button for commits if you've entered them during a review to which they belong?
fields.summary: As a user I would like a back button to the pull request overview page from commits

fields.description:
There should be an immediate email notification if a PR fails to merge successfully due to base branch changes so the developer of the feature waiting for approval knows that they have work to do.

This helps speed up the overall development process as well because the developer does not have to check their outstanding pull requests for merge conflicts periodically.
fields.summary: Email notification for when theoretical merge fails for a pull request
/status resource returns "ERROR" instead of "STARTING" during startup

fields.description:
All other settings save fine, but trying to disable Analytics with JS off results in an error page saying the POST method is not allowed (and the setting is not changed).

The form action for this page is set to "#" whilst other forms simply have a blank action - apparently this causes a different behaviour.
fields.summary: Disabling Analytics does not work without JavaScript turned on

fields.description:
We have a situation where we have 100's of short term projects per year, that last a week or two (we currently use SVN for them). The code is rarely reused or accessed again. We know we can zip up and archive the git repositories, but not the project data in Stash. We don't want to end up with a stash display of hundreds of inactive projects. 

This would also apply to projects that are EOL, but may need to be retrievable to protect our IP.

I know we could hide the projects, by making them read-only to one user, but they will still be there, in the databases.

Thank you.
fields.summary: Question: is there a way to archive projects in Stash?

There is no POST request to JIRA server to update development panel. JIRA Issue Development Panel branch number is not updated instantly
After waiting for a while, then only the branch number is updated

h3.Workaround
# Make sure that JIRA base URL is http://localhost:8080 
# Create the Application Link
# Modify the Display URL to be http://ipaddress:8080 in the Application Link
fields.summary: JIRA Issue Development Panel branch number not updated instantly

fields.description:
When a pull request is opened, all our issues transition to a new state as we've set up in JIRA. But, when an issue is added to an already open pull request, the same trigger won't fire, and the issue doesn't automatically transition.

Consider a situation in which there is a "development" and "testing" states in JIRA, and there is a trigger that whenever a pull request is opened, all issues for that pull request should move from development to testing.

So:
- I create a branch with DIS-1, and DIS-2, and then open a pull request on that branch.
- DIS-1 and DIS-2 are moved to "testing" in JIRA.
- QA finds a bug an opens DIS-3 issue in JIRA on the bug.
- I go back and fix it in the branch with the open pull request, and I note the DIS-3 JIRA key in the commit, and I push.

Behavior I'd expect: Because DIS-3 is now part of an open pull request, it should transition to "testing"
What actually happens: The issue only makes it to development, because while the commit trigger happened to move the issue from open to development, the pull request created trigger did not fire on the issue to move it from in development to in testing.

Logically, the reason this is happening is because the commit was not actually part of a pull request creation event... But... For usage, it might make sense to fire the pull request creation event triggers for an issue that just got moved into an already active pull request.

At least for this component, it's a big deal because it means we're still spending chunks of time in JIRA moving issue that got missed by automatic issue transitioning.
fields.summary: New Issues In Already Open Pull Request Don't Fire Triggers

fields.description:
When I create a comment to a pull request in Stash, I'd like to be able to type 'tab' then 'enter' to submit the comment (keeps my hands on the keyboard).

The current behavior when creating a comment is that 'tab' highlights the Syntax Help button, another 'tab' highlights the Preview button, and the third 'tab' highlights the Comment button. The *vast* majority of comments require the Comment button to be pressed--syntax help and preview are much more rare!

(This feature suggestion also applies to Jira, where the 'tab' ordering is different, but equally sub-optimal--Preview, Syntax Help, Create another, then Create.)
fields.summary: As a user, when creating a comment, I'd like 'tab' to highlight the "Comment" button

fields.description:
We're running Stash & JIRA in our Company and usually committing Changes with a JIRA Issues Key within the Commit-Message to display the Issue within the Repository Log view.

However Stash seems to thread anything like "abc-1" or "OPS-665" as a regular JIRA Issue. This however isn't always true as we've done a lot of Commits like "Update Coding Style to be PSR-2". Stash does actually thread "PSR-2" as an Issue and links that to JIRA. There isn't even a project on JIRA which is called "PSR" (and therefor no such Issue Key).

It'd be nice if Stash could fire a Lookup in JIRA if there's a project (or even an issue) before setting such a link on the web. It's not a major Problem, however our Product-Owners/Project-Managers do get confused by this behavior from time to time.
fields.summary: Issue-Links from Repository Log to JIRA is sometimes wrong

fields.description:
Currently when you merge a pull request in Stash, the resulting commit message for the merge includes the messages from all the individual commits being merged. This causes us problems because we use Crucible to generate release reports, and merging from our release branch into develop (for hot fixes added to release after cutting the branch off develop) causes JIRAs from previous releases to be included in the report for the next release.

It would be great to have an option to NOT include the individual commit messages in the merge commit.
fields.summary: Add option for not including individual commit messages in pull request merge commit messages

fields.description:
We are running Stash as a service on Windows 2012. According to the documentation, we should simply have to run the new installer, point it at the existing home directory, and everything should work. We have made only minor changes, such as changing the user that the service runs as, as we have security policies that dictate anything that connects to a Microsoft SQL database must be a domain user.

When I run the new Stash installer, several things do not happen:
- The Stash Windows service path is not changed. Starting the Stash service will simply start Tomcat in the old versions directory.
- The Tomcat service itself is not updated. This makes things really weird. Even if I change the path of the Windows service, it will reference all the resources in the old directory. I have to manually enter the Tomcat administration tools and update where the Stash Tomcat service it's looking for all it's resources.

It's something I can do rather quickly, but it worries me. In the event I'm hit by a bus, these are extra steps someone else would have to go through and understand. It also introduces a possibility I could make a human error.

From when I can tell, the user I run the installer as should have rights to do all these things, but I also don't remember seeing a UAC prompt. I'm more familiar with the Mac, so possibly there is a security policy causing this issue I'm unaware of. If that is the case, I would like the installer to warn me about that.
fields.summary: Stash Upgrades On Windows Do Not Behave As Documented

fields.description:
In rare edge cases where {{git rev-list --no-walk ...}} doesn't return the commit Stash was expecting before its parents, because their dates are out of order, Stash may display this error on certain pull requests.

{code}
An error occurred
'/usr/bin/git rev-list --format=%H%x02%P%x02%aN%x02%aE%x02%at%n%B%n%x03END%x04 --no-walk 8a1b904f0fa31dd32305c9c219dcf03cc11239a5 8a1b904f0fa31dd32305c9c219dcf03cc11239a5^@ --' exited with code 141
{code}

*Final fix:* 
After upgrading Stash to a fixed version (3.6.1, 3.7.0, etc.), you will also need to upgrade *Git* _on the server_ to 1.8+.

fields.description:
When clicking the "Clone using SourceTree" button in Stash, SSH is the default selection.  We should be allowed to make this default to HTTPS rather than SSH, so we don't have to manually change to HTTPS from SSH each time we want to clone.  Ideally this would be a per-user setting as some may prefer SSH and some may prefer HTTPS.

If you have SSH keys added for another reason (i.e. Bamboo), then it always defaults to SSH.
fields.summary: Allow HTTPS to be the default option for the "Clone using SourceTree" button in Stash.

fields.description:
The database query performed by {{RepositoryService.findByOrigin(Repository, PageRequest)}} does not apply an {{order by}} clause. This means forks are returned in arbitrary order, which makes paging for this call unreliable. Since there's no explicit order, there's no guarantee forks on the second and subsequent pages didn't appear on a previous page, or that any given fork will ever appear on _any_ page if the number of forks exceeds the page limit.

This has a knock-on effect in that it makes fork syncing, which uses it, unreliable. If a given repository has more than 25 forks, syncing may not be performed for some of them.
fields.summary: RepositoryService.findByOrigin doesn't order the returned forks

fields.description:
I really like discussion capabilities as part of stash pull requests.
Why not have something similar at any time? Image "code reviews" at any branch at any time of a stash repo. Code reviews chould allow to invite reviewers to review certain files, one branch, several branches, all branches of a repository.
On top of that admins should be enabled to define restrictions (e.g. do not allow creation of pull requests if a code review is not finished)

Suggestion for code review states:
* opened
* closed
* canceled

roles:
* initiator
* reviewer
* guest
* admin

actions:
* open (admin, initiator)
* comment (admin, initiator, reviewer maybe guest)
* cancel (admin, initiator, reviewer)
* block (admin, initiator, reviewer) - meaning no pull requests are allowed
* approve (admin, initiator, reviewer) 
* read (admin, initiator, reviewer, guest)
* answer (admin, initiator, reviewer, guest)
* rate comment/answer  (admin, initiator, reviewer, guest)

* create task (admin, initiator, reviewer) - could be a jira ticket/task or a stash tasks e.g. add a test for method xyz
* resolve task (admin, initiator, reviewer)
* reopen task (admin, initiator, reviewer)
* cancel task (admin, initiator, reviewer)

* creation restriction rule (admin)
* drop restriction rule (admin)

* add notification (admin, initiator, reviewer, guest)
fields.summary: Code reviews similar to Pull requests at any time of the development

fields.description:
When creating a user, the administrator has the option to send an email to the new user's email address so that he can set his or her password.

However, for a user created in a _Internal with LDAP authentication_ directory, the email will be ineffective because the user's password is set in LDAP and not Stash. (Contrary to JIRA or Confluence, Stash disables write access to remote user directories. As a result, Stash cannot remotely set the user's password in LDAP).
fields.summary: Block the creation of a user if sending a password-reset email would be ineffective

fields.description:
As a System Administrator, we would like to be able to turn off the _Default Permission_ configuration for projects, so that Project Administrators cannot assign read or write access to all logged in users, as is currently the case. When the _Default Permission_ feature is turned off, all projects should be set to "No Access".

The reason is that with a large user and project admin base, we can enforce security only by manual review, which is costly.
fields.summary: Disable Project Default Permission configuration

fields.description:
Hi,

reference to question https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/11961357/ad-synchronisation-fails
We are having issues with syncing are AD server.
It seems like the some entries have the special char "\0A" in cn (new line i guess) which causes the following exception, part1cn(before new line) part2cn(after new line).
I understand that this entry is bad but I expect Stash/Crowed to ignore this entry and continue the sync.
Does this exception causes the sync to halt?
if it does is it possible to ignore this entry and continue the sync
if it doesn't, maybe "Synchronisation failed" should be rephrased to "Synchronisation completed with errors" ?

Looks like this weird cn names is how Active directory is handling duplicate entries http://social.technet.microsoft.com/wiki/contents/articles/15435.active-directory-duplicate-object-name-resolution.aspx#When_a_Duplicate_RDN_in_an_OU_or_Container_is_Detected
Our SonarQube, Subversion Edge and Jenkins can handle this bad entries perfectly fine but Stash have trouble with it.

fields.description:
Although Bitbucket Server provides an API to implement hook reacting on different events inside Stash there is no standard protocol defined which can be used by various external tools, e.g. CI servers, dashboards, etc. It would be beneficial if a "standard" protocol for a set of common events is provided by Bitbucket Server directly. This would ease the integration into other tools as not each tool has to reinvent a protocol to be used but can rely on a standard protocol defined by Atlassian.

[https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/POST+service+webhook+for+Stash] is already going into this direction but currently covers only one use case.

At least the following use cases would be useful:
 * PR Created
 * PR Source Branch Updated
 * PR Target Branch Updated
 * PR Reopened

 

These should be configurable for repositories through the UI and via REST
fields.summary: Standard webhook protocol for common events

fields.description:
Currently the payload of a POST service webhook as described in 
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/POST+service+webhook+for+Stash contains not the full URL of the stash instance but only a relative URL or no URL information at all. This is a problem where the receiver gets triggered by different stash instances as then by just looking at the payload it is not clear anymore from which Stash instance the request is coming from. One can of course try to get the stash instance information from the HTTP request, but this is not very convenient and requires additional work. Therefore it would be better if the webhook is self-contained, .i.e. contains the complete URL information for all the important information e.g. path to projects, repositories, commits. etc.

See also https://developer.github.com/webhooks/#payloads for examples how github is solving this.
fields.summary: POST service webhook should contain full URL of Stash instance

	at com.google.template.soy.base.SoySyntaxException.createWithoutMetaInfo(SoySyntaxException.java:52) ~[na:na]"
fields.summary: Detect and prevent startup when the installation path contains spaces and consider allowing Stash to start in a directory containing spaces

fields.description:
Currently the documentation for automatic branch merge does not mention that the default branch will also be part of the merge. All it stays is that release branches will be considered.

My test setup:
develop is my default branch, three release branches that branched out from develop. I create a bugfix branch from develop, make a change, and generate a Pull Request from my bugfix branch to release/1.0. Based on current documentation the target branches for my merge would be release/1.0, release/1.1 and release/1.2, and not include my default. The screenshot shows the actual result were the default branch is included.
fields.summary: Documentation for automatic merge should state that the default branch is also the target

fields.description:
If i use the newest version of Postgree SQL (PostgreSQL 9.4.0),
then a big red bar appears above the content.

It says "The current database, PostgreSQL 9.4.0, is not supported. You should migrate to a supported database."

the newest version of PostgreeSQl should be supported!
fields.summary: Add PostgreSQL 9.4.0 support

fields.description:
Stash fails to startup if {{audit.highest.priority.to.log}} is set with an unsupported value.

This is a configuration setting that controls how many audit events get logged in your {{STASH_HOME/log/audit/atlassian-stash-audit*.log}}. 

*Problem:*
If the value attributed to that parameter isn't one of the supported values Stash will fail to come up. Stash doesn't check that before trying to convert it to an enum value.  

Here are the supported values:

{noformat:title=atlassian-stash.log}
# Defines the lowest priority audit events that will be logged. This does not affect items stored in the audit log UI.
# Accepted values are: HIGH, MEDIUM, LOW and NONE. Setting the value to HIGH will result in only HIGH level events being logged
# NONE will cause no events to be logged. MEDIUM will only allow events with a priority of MEDIUM and HIGH to be logged.
audit.highest.priority.to.log=HIGH
{noformat}

*PS:* 'low' is in *unsupported* and it will fail. It needs to be in all caps.

*Log of the failure:*

fields.description:
The customer said:

We are interested in documenting our code with the use of PlantUML (http://plantuml.sourceforge.net/index.html). There is an existing PlantUML plugin for Confluence, but we would like something similar for Stash. Ideally, this would be some extension of the markdown support, so we could embed diagrams within .md pages. Alternatively, this could be a visualisation for .puml files. This should include full PlantUML support - some diagrams would require GraphViz to be available on the Stash server.
fields.summary: Visualising similar plugin like PlantUML, integrated in Stash

fields.description:
For many versions this has been a huge complaint of mine and a complaint of others in our development team.

On your filebrowser-readme class for the div element that renders a markdown file you explicitly set the max-width to 1200px. Why? Not everyone has the same monitor resolution as you. There is absolutely no reason to not use 100% here. In fact, most of our devs get so annoyed by this that we use a greasemonkey script to override your CSS and set it to 100% so it looks normal.

A lot of developers now are using large monitors, more specifically 27-30" so you guys need to make this element fit appropriately. I have attached an example of this before and after so you can understand what I mean.

Before:
http://i.imgur.com/VPfRqA8.png

After:
http://i.imgur.com/cVADT7Y.png

Please look into this issue to resolve this. It's been around forever and an explicit 1200px really doesn't apply with large screens.

This is also especially important as we are trying to use stash as a central location to keep some of the application documentation in a similiar way that you can use with GitHub.
fields.summary: Set Markdown max-width to 100%

fields.description: In the diff view for a particular pull request, some of the wrong lines are being colored red and green. It looks like the highlight is supposed to be on the line directly below. Also, there is an extra line at the bottom of the diff, below the "cut" or "rip". The colors seem to line up until after a line that just includes a "\", so perhaps that could be triggering the problem?
fields.summary: Pull request diff shows changes on wrong line

fields.description: A feature request to reject commits to a repository based on configurable rules (like the plugin "Yet Another Commit Checker") to integrate with Stash.
fields.summary: Integrate a plugin like Yet Another Commit Checker into Stash

fields.description:
*Background*

In Japan, there are so many charsets. So it will be difficult to specify the correct charset automatically.
So there should be the function that allows users to select charset (e.g. utf-8, windows-31j, x-eucJP-Open, x-MS9320213 and so on. ) for each repository.
If there is this function, customer will be able to prevent from facing the garbled character in many case.
fields.summary: Allow users to select charset for each repository

fields.description:
As a system administrator I would like to track my configuration files in Stash.
The content will be checked out with a system access key, without a user account. At present the system allows to restrict the system access to read only mode (which is great).

Would be nice to be able to restrict the system access by branch as well - to enforce a specific branch per key.
fields.summary: System access limited by branch

fields.description:
The guidance instructions for resolving automatic merge conflicts is destructive. 

We have a branching structure where we have a release branch that forks from master. The instructions suggest that user should first merge the target branch into the current source branch, before merging that back into the master. The developer then pushed those changes in his local release branch back up to Stash, and the changes proliferated from there.

It would be better if the suggestion were to merge up into a branch based off the source branch, rather than directly into the source branch itself. This would have saved a major headache.
fields.summary: The guidance for resolving automatic merge conflicts is destructive

fields.description:
Currently the stash restore client requires the admin to delete all files in the home directory and to drop all tables, etc. in the database.

It would be convenient if there was a "--force" option for the restore client to do this itself.
fields.summary: Add option to stash restore client to clear home directory and database

fields.description:
Currently the restore client requires that the stash home directory be empty.  

This requirement is problematic when the home directory is a NFS mounted NetApp volume/qtree where the volume has snapshots enabled, as it will contain a .snapshot directory.

The .snapshot directory can not be removed, it must be disabled by the storage administrator. But disabling snapshots also affects every other qtree on the volume.

For a recent restore, I had to have our storage admin temporarily disable snapshots. Even though the restore was brief, it turns out that there were users that needed to access their .snapshot directory during that time.
fields.summary: Allow stash restore client to write to filesystem with NetApp .snapshot directory

fields.description:
You cannot set loose “Project Permissions” and then tighter “Repository permissions” because the repository permission will inherit the project permissions and allow even more people access 

eg. I would like the project permissions (effectively the default permissions for all repositories) to be group ABC has access, but for one particular repository X, I want to have just me be able to access it, not group ABC. 

Currently, this seems to be impossible. I would have to set me as having access in the project permissions, then for all repositories (and there may be many) except X, set group ABC. For all new repositories, I would have to remember to change the repository settings to allow group ABC.
fields.summary: Repository permissions should optionally override project permissions

fields.description:
Currently we merge most of our pull requests manually. This is to avoid merge commit creation where possible, and also to give a chance for our developers to apply any fixes which they need to make locally.

Once a pull request has been merged in this way, the only way to close it is to mark it as "declined". In this situation however, declined is not indicative of what actually happened to the pull request (it was merged manually).

I suggest that either "declined" is changed to "closed", or a new pull request status is added.
fields.summary: Change "declined" to a friendlier verb or add a new pull request status.
